qas.question: What was the first recorded history of this region?
What was modern Tajikistan part of around 500 BE?
Who took over the territory and made it part of their empire?
Very little of modern Tajikistan was part of what empire?
Alexandra the Great ruled over which kingdom?
Which part of Tajikistan was part of Singdia?
The Japanese explorer Zhang Qian used what road to pass through the region?
Who played a major role on ending trade?

context: The earliest recorded history of the region dates back to <a0_0>about 500 BCE<a0_0/> when much, if not all, of modern Tajikistan was part of <a1_0>the Achaemenid Empire<a1_0/>. Some authors have also suggested that in the 7th and 6th century BCE parts of modern Tajikistan, including territories in the Zeravshan valley, formed part of Kambojas before it became part of <b3_0>the Achaemenid Empire<b3_0/>. After the region's conquest by <a2_0>Alexander the Great<a2_0/> it became part of <b4_0>the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom<b4_0/>, a successor state of Alexander's empire. <b5_0>Northern<b5_0/> Tajikistan (the cities of Khujand and Panjakent) was part of Sogdia, a collection of city-states which was overrun by Scythians and Yuezhi nomadic tribes around 150 BCE. <b6_0>The Silk Road<b6_0/> passed through the region and following the expedition of Chinese explorer Zhang Qian during the reign of Wudi (141–87 BCE) commercial relations between Han China and Sogdiana flourished. <b7_0>Sogdians<b7_0/> played a major role in facilitating trade and also worked in other capacities, as farmers, carpetweavers, glassmakers, and woodcarvers.
